item.title: Jonathan Millam
item.description: Jon is a St. Thomas Computer Engineering student. In the research lab, Jon has investigated material classfication using time-of-flight transients. Jon loves to code and is the lab PyTorch machine learning expert.

item.title: Jordan Haag
item.description: Jordan is a UST electrical engineering major and Air Force ROTC student. He loves PCB design and test and has contributed two PCB designs to the COVG amplifier project. He is a recipient of an Air Force graduate program scholarship to continue his electrical engineering studies after UST.

item.title: Kordt Gammelgaard
item.description: Kordt Gammelgaard is a UST EE major with an interest in physics. In the summer of 2023, Kordt received a UROP Young scholars grant to explore material classification with time-of-flight sensors. He adeptly used his experimental and broad design skills to significantly improve our test setup.

item.title: William Schneider
item.description: Will, a sophomore from a small town in central Minnesota, is studying mechanical engineering and researching the electrical properties of conductive filaments for 3D printers. His primary interest is horology, but he also finds 3D printers, RC systems, and high powered rockets interesting. He codes well (even in C++)!

item.title: Ian Bonequi Delgadillo
item.description: Ian is a second-year student at St. Thomas, currently pursuing a degree in Electrical Engineering. His current responsibility is developing Verilog code for the COVG amplifier project. He is coding modules that will connect to a host computer using the Opal Kelly Front Panel interface, which allow the host computer to control analog to digital and digital to analog converters, through the use of an SPI interface and a Wishbone bus.
